body: THE statistics say New York just went through a spike in crime. Want to know what a spike feels like? Come to East New York. Walk around New Lots Avenue beneath the elevated subway station and look around. You'll see them. The unsmiling guys in the hooded sweatshirts and bubble jackets. The ones whose eyes never meet yours. They're back, blatantly
title: Metro Matters; Like Avatars Of Crime, They're Back

body: FARRELL-Hazel (nee Medford). Of Freehold, NJ and Woodhaven, NY, October 31, 2001, in her 88th year. Beloved widow of James E. Farrell, whom she married on her 21st birthday in 1935. Devoted mother of Carol and Walter Bennett, of Freehold, NJ; Margaret and Gerald Nelson, of Brooklyn, NY; and James E. Farrell, Jr. and Gail Farrell, of Garden City,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FARRELL, HAZEL (NEE MEDFORD)

body: The chaos in the streets, the screams, the people running every direction, the smoke and fire reminded Robert Sanchez of his tour of duty in Vietnam. ''That was exactly what it looked like before we went into a village,'' he recalled. ''It was a flashback and a half. I'm scared of that. I don't want it to catch me later on.'' But Mr. Sanchez, a
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: CHARITY; Attacks Revive Memories of Vietnam

body: WEHMHOEFER-Ruth M. On July 11, 2001. Loving sister of Robert Wehmhoefer. Dear aunt of Tara Dill and Kevin Wehmhoefer. Resposing Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Avenue (corner Lefferts Boulevard) Richmond Hill. Service Sunday 5PM, St.Peter's Lutheran Church. Funeral Monday 10AM from church. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. Visiting Saturday
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WEHMHOEFER, RUTH M.

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. Sunday at 1 p.m., ''From Stuyvesants to Immigrants: Social Upheaval in the East Village,'' a waking tour of the Bond Street neighborhood, concluding with a guided tour of the museum; admission, $12, includes a guided tour of the house. A self-guided tour is
title: SPARE TIMES

body: At the start of a predicted spell of scorching weather, a group that includes some of New York City's largest businesses and building owners agreed yesterday to take steps to conserve energy, like scaling back the use of air-conditioners. The arrival yesterday of 90-plus-degree temperatures around the New York region drove power consumption up,
title: The Heat Is On, and Businesses Strive to Keep the Power On, Too

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has opened, with the same hours as the museum. ''The Genomic Revolution,'' examines the genome, genetics, developments involving molecular biology and the impact on
title: SPARE TIMES

body: One candidate for City Council invited guests to participate in an ''Extreme Bowling Night,'' several slightly odd hours of throwing 16-pound balls down dimly lighted lanes in a Queens alley. Nights earlier in Brooklyn, another candidate staged an event featuring ''spoken word artists,'' where for $10 one could listen to hip-hop or poetry and
title: A Dash for Campaign Cash; Creative Fund-Raising Spreads in Year of Term Limits

body: MILLS-Lillian C. (nee Clune) on May 22, 2001, of Amityville, LI (formerly of NYC). Beloved wife of the late John Henry Mills. Loving sister of Dorothy Lantz and the late Frances Clune. Dear sister-inlaw of Edward Lantz. Cherished aunt of Jane Lantz, Robert and Dorothy Lantz, John and Jozefina Lantz, and Ellen and Carl Andersen. Special aunt of ten
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MILLS, LILLIAN C. (NEE CLUNE)

body: The state-appointed mediator for New York City's stalled teacher talks has vowed to step up the pace of negotiations later this week, and many of the pieces appear in place for a deal. The union representing 80,000 public school teachers has signaled that it would agree to more work and some form of merit pay -- two items that Mayor Rudolph W.
title: Hurdles, but Signs of Hope for a Teachers' Contract

body: Richly Decorated Nassau County Museum of Art, Northern Boulevard, two blocks west of Glen Cove Road, Roslyn Harbor, N.Y.; (516) 484-9337. ''Reflections of Opulence: Art Nouveau to Art Deco,'' an exhibition of cabinets, chairs, paintings, lamps, vases and windows, opens Sunday and runs through Aug. 5. The 200 objects, reflecting the international
title: CALENDAR

body: New York City's teachers union, which has long opposed the concept of merit pay, has sought to end a negotiating deadlock by signaling that it may accept a version of incentive pay, but one far different from that proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The union, the United Federation of Teachers, indicated over the last week that it would
title: Union Signals Softer Stance On Merit Pay

body: No one is more surprised that Queens has so many American Indians than the American Indians in Queens. Nearly 6,300 American Indians and Alaskans called Queens home on the 2000 Census, more than in any other county in the state. ''I can't find anyone,'' said Shirley Cuffey, a Powhatan woman who lives in East Elmhurst, and then she gave one reason.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS UP CLOSE; It's Home to Shea, La Guardia . . . And U.S. Indians

body: THREE weeks ago, The New York Times invited children from the public schools to submit essays on problems in their schools and how to correct them. Hundreds of essays were received; here are some excerpts: Teachers, Classes . . . I'd have more labs where you can study animal behavior and put mouse and cockroach traps on the floor so that the
title: SOAPBOX; Sitting in Mom's Old Desk
